--- title: "Anomaly Detection" author: "Rishav Khatiwada" date: "2023-11-19" categories: [news, code, analysis] image: "image1.jpg" --- Importing the required libraries: ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as pl import seaborn as sns from scipy import stats from sklearn.ensemble import IsolationForest from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler from sklearn.cluster import DBSCAN from sklearn.metrics import silhouette_score, silhouette_samples from sklearn.decomposition import PCA ``` ::: importing the dataset: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} data=pd.read_csv('kalimati_tarkari_dataset.csv',index_col='SN') data.head ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ``` ``` ::: ::: Only selecting the data January 1st 2020 onward which we are interested in: ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} specific_date_1 = pd.to_datetime('2020-01-01') data['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Date']) specific_date = pd.to_datetime(specific_date_1) data = data[data['Date'] > specific_date] data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}
Commodity Date Unit Minimum Maximum Average
SN
157524 Tomato Big(Nepali) 2020-01-02 Kg 65.0 70.0 67.5
157525 Tomato Big(Indian) 2020-01-02 Kg 65.0 70.0 67.5
157526 Tomato Small(Local) 2020-01-02 Kg 40.0 50.0 45.0
157527 Tomato Small(Tunnel) 2020-01-02 Kg 40.0 50.0 45.0
157528 Tomato Small(Indian) 2020-01-02 KG 40.0 50.0 45.0
... ... ... ... ... ... ...

197157 Fish Fresh(Rahu) 2021-05-13 KG 270.0 280.0 275.0
197158 Fish Fresh(Bachuwa) 2021-05-13 KG 225.0 235.0 230.0
197159 Fish Fresh(Chhadi) 2021-05-13 KG 220.0 230.0 225.0
197160 Fish Fresh(Mungari) 2021-05-13 KG 240.0 250.0 245.0

39637 rows × 6 columns

``` ::: ::: Saving the commodity and date columns in its original form so that it can be used later as we will be converting them using label encoder. ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} Commodity = data['Commodity'].tolist() Date = data['Date'].tolist() ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} pl.scatter(data.iloc[:,3],data.iloc[:,4]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-6-output-2.png){width=583 height=411} ::: ::: Identifying the missing values: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} data.apply(pd.isnull).sum()/data.shape[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` Commodity 0.0 Date 0.0 Unit 0.0 Minimum 0.0 Maximum 0.0 Average 0.0 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Describing the data to know the details of our features: ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} data.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
Date Minimum Maximum Average
count 39637 39637.000000 39637.000000 39637.000000
mean 2020-09-27 03:02:53.020158208 100.141787 110.051518 105.096652
min 2020-01-02 00:00:00 6.000000 8.000000 7.000000
25% 2020-05-25 00:00:00 40.000000 50.000000 45.000000

std NaN 92.813213 97.867785 95.277303
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.distplot(data["Average"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` C:\Users\poude\AppData\Local\Temp\ipykernel_19400\1442402836.py:1: UserWarning: `distplot` is a deprecated function and will be removed in seaborn v0.14.0. Please adapt your code to use either `displot` (a figure-level function with similar flexibility) or `histplot` (an axes-level function for histograms). For a guide to updating your code to use the new functions, please see https://gist.github.com/mwaskom/de44147ed2974457ad6372750bbe5751 sns.distplot(data["Average"]) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-9-output-3.png){width=615 height=429} ::: ::: From this we can see that the data is right skewed. To perform the anomaly detection we can use different models. Here, we will discuss some of the models but eventually we will be using DBSCAN. First, we test the z_score to find anomaly. ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} price = ['Minimum', 'Maximum', 'Average'] z_scores = stats.zscore(data[price]) threshold = 2 anamoly1 = data[(z_scores > threshold).any(axis=1)] print(anamoly1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Commodity Date Unit Minimum Maximum Average SN 157571 Mushroom(Button) 2020-01-02 KG 330.0 340.0 335.0 157598 Chilli Dry 2020-01-02 Kg 390.0 400.0 395.0 157657 Mushroom(Button) 2020-01-03 KG 340.0 350.0 345.0 157684 Chilli Dry 2020-01-03 Kg 390.0 400.0 395.0 157742 Mushroom(Button) 2020-01-04 KG 320.0 330.0 325.0 ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 197054 Strawberry 2021-05-12 Kg 400.0 500.0 450.0 197056 Chilli Dry 2021-05-12 Kg 320.0 330.0 325.0 197114 Asparagus 2021-05-13 Kg 1000.0 1050.0 1025.0 197145 Strawberry 2021-05-13 Kg 450.0 500.0 475.0 197147 Chilli Dry 2021-05-13 Kg 320.0 330.0 325.0 [2208 rows x 6 columns] ``` ::: ::: Second, we use interquartile range(IQR) for anomaly detection. ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} Q1 = data[price].quantile(0.25) Q3 = data[price].quantile(0.75) IQR = Q3 - Q1 threshold = 1.5 anamoly2 = data[((data[price] < (Q1 - threshold * IQR)) | (data[price] > (Q3 + threshold * IQR))).any(axis=1)] print(anamoly2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Commodity Date Unit Minimum Maximum Average SN 157571 Mushroom(Button) 2020-01-02 KG 330.0 340.0 335.0 157575 Celery 2020-01-02 Kg 270.0 280.0 275.0 157576 Parseley 2020-01-02 Kg 270.0 280.0 275.0 157578 Mint 2020-01-02 Kg 270.0 280.0 275.0 157583 Gundruk 2020-01-02 Kg 280.0 290.0 285.0 ... ... ... ... ... ... ... 197130 Pomegranate 2021-05-13 Kg 280.0 300.0 290.0 197141 Pear(Chinese) 2021-05-13 Kg 250.0 260.0 255.0 197145 Strawberry 2021-05-13 Kg 450.0 500.0 475.0 197147 Chilli Dry 2021-05-13 Kg 320.0 330.0 325.0 197157 Fish Fresh(Rahu) 2021-05-13 KG 270.0 280.0 275.0 [4039 rows x 6 columns] ``` ::: ::: Selecting the numerical features of which we want to detect anomalies: ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} price = ['Minimum', 'Maximum', 'Average'] model = IsolationForest(contamination=0.05) model.fit(data[price]) anomaly = model.predict(data[price]) anomaly ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` array([1, 1, 1, ..., 1, 1, 1]) ``` ::: ::: And performing the element-wise comparison ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} price = np.where(anomaly < 0) price ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` (array([ 47, 74, 133, ..., 39590, 39621, 39623], dtype=int64),) ``` ::: ::: Making our earlier scatter plot more beautiful: ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} new_price=data.values pl.scatter(data.iloc[:,3],data.iloc[:,4]) pl.scatter(new_price[price,3],new_price[price,4],edgecolor='blue') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-14-output-2.png){width=583 height=411} ::: ::: Converting our Date features to a numerical format and converting that timestamp into an integer: ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} data["Date"] = pd.to_datetime(data["Date"]).apply(lambda x: x.timestamp()) data["Date"] = data["Date"].astype(int) data.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` C:\Users\poude\AppData\Local\Temp\ipykernel_19400\2041701408.py:1: SettingWithCopyWarning: A value is trying to be set on a copy of a slice from a DataFrame. Try using .loc[row_indexer,col_indexer] = value instead See the caveats in the documentation: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/indexing.html#returning-a-view-versus-a-copy data["Date"] = pd.to_datetime(data["Date"]).apply(lambda x: x.timestamp()) C:\Users\poude\AppData\Local\Temp\ipykernel_19400\2041701408.py:3: SettingWithCopyWarning: A value is trying to be set on a copy of a slice from a DataFrame. Try using .loc[row_indexer,col_indexer] = value instead See the caveats in the documentation: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/indexing.html#returning-a-view-versus-a-copy data["Date"] = data["Date"].astype(int) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html}
Commodity Date Unit Minimum Maximum Average
SN
157524 Tomato Big(Nepali) 1577923200 Kg 65.0 70.0 67.5
157525 Tomato Big(Indian) 1577923200 Kg 65.0 70.0 67.5
157526 Tomato Small(Local) 1577923200 Kg 40.0 50.0 45.0
157527 Tomato Small(Tunnel) 1577923200 Kg 40.0 50.0 45.0
157528 Tomato Small(Indian) 1577923200 KG 40.0 50.0 45.0
``` ::: ::: TO maintain the consistency, we choose to use standard scalar to scale our data: ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} data = data.drop("Commodity",axis=1) data = data.drop("Unit",axis=1) scaler = StandardScaler() data = scaler.fit_transform(data) ``` ::: Reducing the dimensions of our data to 2 using PCA: ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} num_components = 2 pca = PCA(n_components=num_components) data = pca.fit_transform(data) data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` array([[-0.79822404, 1.77395273], [-0.79822404, 1.77395273], [-1.20721222, 1.74699569], ..., [ 2.36499445, -1.39243537], [ 2.27428372, -1.39829777], [ 2.63712665, -1.37484816]]) ``` ::: ::: Performing the DBSCAN clustering using PCA component 1 and 2 each representing one dimension. ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} eps = 0.6 min_samples = 10 dbscan = DBSCAN(eps=eps, min_samples=min_samples) dbscan.fit(data) pl.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) sns.scatterplot(x=data[:, 0], y=data[:, 1], hue=dbscan.labels_, palette='viridis', legend='full') anomaly_mask = dbscan.labels_ == -1 sns.scatterplot(x=data[anomaly_mask, 0], y=data[anomaly_mask, 1], color='red', marker='x', label='Anomalies') pl.title("DBSCAN Clustering with Anomalies (PCA-transformed)") pl.xlabel("PCA Component 1") pl.ylabel("PCA Component 2") pl.legend() pl.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-18-output-1.png){width=823 height=523} ::: ::: To see the performance of our Clustering model, we use Silhouette Score: ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} silhouette_avg = silhouette_score(data, dbscan.labels_) print(f"Silhouette Score: {silhouette_avg}") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Silhouette Score: 0.8130632448850426 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} cluster_labels = dbscan.fit_predict(data) data = pd.DataFrame({'x': data[:, 0], 'y': data[:, 1], 'cluster': cluster_labels, 'Date': Date,"Commodity":Commodity}) data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ```{=html}
x y cluster Date Commodity
0 -0.798224 1.773953 0 2020-01-02 Tomato Big(Nepali)
1 -0.798224 1.773953 0 2020-01-02 Tomato Big(Indian)
2 -1.207212 1.746996 0 2020-01-02 Tomato Small(Local)
3 -1.207212 1.746996 0 2020-01-02 Tomato Small(Tunnel)
4 -1.207212 1.746996 0 2020-01-02 Tomato Small(Indian)
... ... ... ... ... ...
39632 0.186357 -1.534286 0 2021-05-13 Garlic Dry Nepali
39633 3.181391 -1.339674 0 2021-05-13 Fish Fresh(Rahu)
39634 2.364994 -1.392435 0 2021-05-13 Fish Fresh(Bachuwa)
39635 2.274284 -1.398298 0 2021-05-13 Fish Fresh(Chhadi)
39636 2.637127 -1.374848 0 2021-05-13 Fish Fresh(Mungari)

39637 rows × 5 columns

``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} pl.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) ax = sns.scatterplot(x="x", y="y", hue="cluster", data=data, palette="viridis", s=100) for x, y, Date, cluster in zip(data['x'], data['y'], data['Date'], data['cluster']): pl.text(x, y, Date, fontsize=10, alpha=0.8) ax.set(ylim=(-3, 3)) pl.xlabel("Principal Component 1", fontsize=15) pl.ylabel("Principal Component 2", fontsize=15) pl.legend(title='Cluster', loc='upper right', labels=[f'Cluster {label}' for label in data['cluster'].unique()]) pl.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-21-output-1.png){width=925 height=515} ::: ::: It is difficult to visualize individual data with so much compact cluster. So, let's try to do it the other way where we break our clusters and visualize only the one that is important to us. Here, these are the anomaly that we wanted to see. ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} data = data[data['cluster'] == -1] ax = sns.scatterplot(x="x", y="y", data=data, color="red", s=100) for x, y, Commodity in zip(data['x'], data['y'], data['Commodity']): pl.text(x, y, Commodity, fontsize=10, alpha=0.8) ax.set(ylim=(-3, 3)) pl.xlabel("Principal Component 1", fontsize=15) pl.ylabel("Principal Component 2", fontsize=15) pl.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-22-output-1.png){width=641 height=441} ::: ::: Let's visualize it more clearly the other way: ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} data = data[data['cluster'] == -1] pl.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) sns.countplot(y='Commodity', data=data, color='green') pl.xlabel("Count", fontsize=15) pl.ylabel("Commodity", fontsize=15) pl.title("Commodity Counts in Cluster -1", fontsize=20) pl.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-23-output-1.png){width=932 height=539} ::: ::: We can see that the Vegetables like Asparagus and Mushroom, spice like Akbare Green Chilli, Fruits like Strawberry which are less consumed in Nepal and are usually more expensive than other vegetables see the anomalies in price. This is simply because people are usually unaware of their actual price as these foods are less consumed in Kathmandu and the whole sellers and retailers take an advantage of this and rise their price citing various reasons like weather, change in fuel price, etc. The suprising commodity that features in this list is Chinese Garlic, which is a popular and most sold spice in Kathmandu. The reason may be the sellers sometime increase the price by creating fake shortage of this product for more profit by saying there has been some problem during import as it is imported from China. This is not very uncommon thing there. So, the concerned authority should really need to pay attention to the sudden increase of the off seasonal and less consumed commodity in addition to the regular ones.
